content:
ASIA

UK

House of Commons voted (307 to 301) to reject New Clause 18 of the Trade Bill which would have required the UK to make it a negotiating objective to establish a free trade area for goods with EU or enable UK participation in a customs union with the EU.

House of Commons voted (305 to 301) to approve New Clause 17 of the Trade Bill which imposes a negotiating objective for the UK government to secure an agreement that allows the continued participation in the European medicines regulatory network. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump said he accepts the intelligence which shows Russia meddled in US elections, while he also commented he hopes that Iran will eventually call them and possibly make a new deal or maybe not. (Newswires)


US

Fed Chair Powell reiterated gradual hikes and that it is difficult to predict how trade policy talks may influence the economy, while he also commented that overall risks are 'roughly balanced'. Powell further stated the US is on target inflation over the next several years with appropriate monetary policy and that recent inflation readings are encouraging, while he noted the latest data suggests US growth was considerably stronger in Q2. (Newswires)

US Agricultural Secretary Perdue said we are getting close to an agreement with Canada and Mexico, while there were also comments from Canadian PM Trudeau that they are going to be able to get a good NAFTA deal. (Newswires)

US Industrial Production (Jun) M/M 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. -0.1%, Rev. -0.5%). (Newswires)
US Manufacturing Production (Jun) M/M 0.8% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. -0.7%, Rev. -1.0%)


MARKET RECAP

After NFLX reported grim earnings aftermarket on Monday, as well as AMZN’s tech issues on its ‘Prime Day’, US Equity futures were negative and sideways in the premarket. However, as the cash day got underway, the bias was to the upside, aided by strong earnings reports from Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) & Charles Schwab (SCHW). Newswires are also attributing the gains to Fed chair of Powell’s semi-annual testimony, where he gave an upbeat assessment of the US economy. However, this was very much a reiteration and he generally avoided rocking the boat. The Emini S&P hit its highest levels in five months, after it broke through the key 2800 level once again. Elsewhere, Goldman Sachs (GS) confirmed the appointment of David Solomon as CEO, and he will take role in October while current CEO Lloyd Blankfein will remain chairman until the end of the year. Goldman also reported numbers, which beat on both top- and bottom-lines, with Q2 FICC revenues higher by 45% Y/Y, though equity revenues were flat y/y. In afternoon trade, shares in US automakers (GM, F) moved higher on news that the EU was considering exploring talks with US President Trump on car-tariff reduction. SPX +0.40% at 2809, NDX +0.63% at 7403, DJI +0.23% at 25121.

The Treasury complex settled lower on Tuesday in typically thin summer volumes, with the yield curve modestly bear-flattening, though yields were more-or—less unchanged. Some parts of the curve hit the flattest level in almost 11 years. Most of the action was concentrated in the front-end where the 2yr yield at its highest level in decade after Fed’s Powell stroke a positive tone on the US economy and avoided comments on the flattening yield curve on Tuesday, while again making upbeat comments on the economy, endorsing gradual hikes. Money markets are now pricing in an 89% probability of a rate hike in September. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 1+ ticks lower at 120-04.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 17th July 2018 - EU mulls auto talks with US, UK government survives pro-EU rebellion
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, oil up, dollar up.
  • REAR-VIEW: Crude stabilises on competing supply-side factors; Powell sticks to the script; EU mulls talks with Trump to cut tariffs; UK government survives pro-EU rebellion.
  • COMING-UP: Fed chair Powell Part 2; UK inflation, DOE inventories; earnings from MS, AXP, USB, IBM, EBAY

* TRADE: EU is reportedly exploring talks with US President Trump on car-tariff reduction, as has been suggested by German press in recent weeks. Japan and Europe on Tuesday signed the largest bilateral trade deal globally in an active move against protectionism on the back of trade tensions between US and China. The pact includes significant concessions from both sides, and is likely to lower Japanese tariffs on food products from Europe, whilst lifting EU tariffs on cars and parts coming from Japan. Note the deal is subject to approval by both European and Japanese lawmakers. Elsewhere, US Agricultural Secretary Perdue said we are getting close to an agreement with Canada and Mexico. The US has requested WTO talks over retaliatory tariffs on US goods. Domestically, there were continued signs that Republicans are pushing back on Trump, after Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee Hatch said he might support a bill to curtail Trump’s trade powers. Separately, ahead of Friday’s G20 meeting, the draft summit communique reportedly mentions trade as a growth engine, and expresses support for multilateral trade rules – the communique was said to face no objection from the US.

* TRUMP: US President Trump conceded that Russia did meddle in the 2016 US Presidential election. On geopolitical matters, Trump said he hopes that Iran will eventually call the US and possibly make a new deal.

* FED: Chairman Powell didn’t rock the boat (once again) in the text of his testimony to the Senate Banking Committee. Powell reiterated the FOMC’s view for gradual rate hikes, noting that overall risks to the US economy appear ‘roughly balanced’. On trade, the Fed chair talked about the difficulties in predicting how trade policy talks might influence the US economy, but said trade uncertainty could be a threat to wage growth. Generally, Powell continued to express optimism on the US economy, stating that the labour market can continue to strengthen over the next ‘several years’, as can inflation. Powell also noted that the run of data shows Q2 growth was considerably stronger, and recent inflation metrics were encouraging. However, some picked-up on signs of caution in Powell’s comments, Scotiabank points out: Powell said “with a strong job market, inflation close to our objective, and the risks to the outlook roughly balanced, the FOMC believes that—for now—the best way forward is to keep gradually raising the federal funds rate.” And Scotia says the rest of that same ‘for now’ paragraph gives the risks of going too fast versus too slow and openness to changing forecasts if needed but not yet, also citing Powell’s line that "as always, our actions will depend on the economic outlook, which may change as we receive new data." Scotiabank writes “None of this is necessarily surprising given data dependency, but “for now” and "may change" could be taken as indicating somewhat less confidence in their forecasts.”

* ECB: ECB’s Rehn said it was wise that monetary policy not tie ones hand if there is no need, adding that markets seem to be reading the ECB’s forward guidance correctly.

* BREXIT: The government defeated an attempted rebellion by pro-EU lawmakers, who attached an amendment in the Trade Bill to compel the UK government to adopt membership of the EU customs union should they fail to push through the deal envisaged by May by January 2019. The win for the government is said to give UK PM May more strength to negotiate her position with the EU. On the news, GBP saw two way action in choppy trade; on the one hand, giving the government more scope to pursue a not-so-soft-Brexit was considered a negative for the UK currency, however, a stable government lent some strength to the pound; the net/net result was GBP was little changed since before the vote took place, though did see some very choppy price action.

* US INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION: IP was up 0.6% in July M/M, in line with expectations, and also saw a jump from the revised -0.1% in June. Mining and utilities were both robust though the gains were only partially offset by a surprising decline in utilities. 75% of the rise in manufacturing was attributed to production resuming in the auto sector after a fire disrupted activity at a truck parts in May, analysts at Oxford Economics noted, the “industrial sector momentum looks favourable at the moment,” though OxEco did warn that “the road ahead looks a bit precarious” as even if higher oil prices and the tax cuts are positive for the industrial sector, a stronger greenback, supply constraints and most importantly trade war uncertainty may weigh on industrial output in the near future. OxEco estimates that the tariffs announced so far could trim 0.4ppts from real GDP growth in the coming year.

* WTI (Q8) SETTLES 2 CENTS HIGHER AT $68.08/BBL; WTI (U8) SETTLES 9 CENTS HIGHER $67.07/BBL; BRENT (U8) SETTLES 32 CENTS HIGHER AT $72.16/BBL. Term structures were moving bearishly in early trade, and at one point in the session, both WTI and Brent front month contracts were in contango (note: the WTI Q8 contract expires on Friday), with concerns of higher output continuing to linger. With that said, there has been some stabilisation in prices following yesterday’s slide, perhaps in part due to the labour strikes in Norway and the geopolitics around Iran, where output is likely to fall as the US reimposes sanctions (note: it was reported that the US has rejected all French, German and British demands on Iran sanctions exemptions). Analysts at PVM said the competing supply-side forces has underpinned widespread uncertainty, which will ensure volatile trading conditions; analysts at Goldman Sachs are also expect crude to trade volatile in the months ahead, and see Brent within a range of $70-$80 per barrel this year. Ultimately, as equities caught a bid in afternoon trade and sentiment became more constructive, crude erased losses for the day.  

* CRUDE OUTPUT: Libya's oil production at Waha is up to 70k-80k BPD from 20k BPD, according to sources; other reports suggested that Libyan output has risen to 650-700k BPD amid port re-openings, sources said (Agoco output was up to 220k BPD, newswires reported on Tuesday, vs the 150-180k BPD on 16 July). However, later in the session, Libya’s state-NOC declared a force majeure on loadings at the Zawiya oil terminal, and the NOC also said output at Sharara had fallen to 125k BPD (from 130k BPD on Monday). Meanwhile, Russian oil output was up by 273k BPD in July to 11.22mln BPD, and output at Iraq's southern oil exports is knocking around 3.566mln BPD in July so far (it was averaging 3.521mln BPD in June). The kicker is that output and exports in Saudi Arabia, Russia and Iraq were higher in the first half of July, and Angola will raise September crude exports to 1.51mln BPD. Amid these developments, chatter of a release from the US Strategic Petroleum Reserve continue to do the rounds.

* INVENTORY EXPECTATIONS: Analysts expect US crude stocks to draw down by 3.6mln in the week, gasoline stocks are seen unchanged, and distillates are forecast to build by 900k. Stocks at the Cushing hub are seen lower by 368k (from 10/Jul) and lower by 1.3mln (from 6/Jul). API reports its weekly inventory data aftermarket on Tuesday.

* SPX +0.40% at 2809, NDX +0.63% at 7403, DJI +0.23% at 25121. SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: +0.79%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +0.10%, Energy: -0.38%, Financials: +0.16%, Health Care: +0.54%, Industrials: +0.38%, Materials: +1.32%, Telecoms: -0.36%, Tech: +0.81%, Utilities: -0.06%.

* FUTURES: After NFLX reported grim earnings aftermarket on Monday, as well as AMZN’s tech issues on its ‘Prime Day’,  US equity US Equity futures were negative and sideways in the premarket. However, as the cash day got underway, the bias was to the upside, aided by strong earnings reports from Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) & Charles Schwab (SCHW). Newswires are also attributing the gains to Fed chair of Powell’s semi-annual testimony, where he gave an upbeat assessment of the US economy. However, this was very much a reiteration and he generally avoided rocking the boat. The Emini S&P hit its highest levels in five months, after it broke through the key 2800 level once again.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Netflix’s (NFLX) was hit in Monday’s AMC trade after reporting light subscriber additions in Q2, though has pared back those losses in Tuesday trade (it was down 14% at one point). Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) earnings beat expectations, however, it cut FY sales guidance, which caused a wobble in the pre-market, though JNJ opened higher and steadily built on gains. Goldman Sachs (GS) confirmed the appointment of David Solomon as CEO, and he will take role in October while current CEO Lloyd Blankfein will remain chairman until the end of the year. Goldman also reported numbers, which beat on both top- and bottom-lines, with Q2 FICC revenues higher by 45% Y/Y, though equity revenues were flat y/y. In afternoon trade, shares in US automakers (GM, F) moved higher on news that the EU was considering exploring talks with US President Trump on car-tariff reduction.

* US 10YR T-NOTES FUTURES (U8) SETTLE 1+ TICKS LOWER AT 120-04. The Treasury complex settled lower on Tuesday in typically thin summer volumes, with the yield curve modestly bear-flattening, though yields were more-or—less unchanged. Some parts of the curve hit the flattest level in almost 11 years. Most of the action was concentrated in the front-end where the 2yr yield at its highest level in decade after Fed’s Powell stroke a positive tone on the US economy and avoided comments on the flattening yield curve on Tuesday, while again making upbeat comments on the economy, endorsing gradual hikes. Money markets are now pricing in an 89% probability of a rate hike in September.

* USD: Dollar strength was attributed to upbeat comments by Fed chair Jerome Powell, who successfully avoided rocking the boat too much in the first part of his semi-annual testimony to congress. However, the initial reaction of the dollar to Powell’s remarks was negative, before the greenback found a bid, and then went on to print HOD above the 95 handle (95.062). US industrial production data also added to the allure of the buck.

* GBP: On the news that the UK government defeated an attempted rebellion by pro-EU lawmakers, GBP saw two way action in choppy trade; on the one hand, giving the government more scope to pursue a not-so-soft-Brexit was considered a negative for the UK currency, however, a stable government lent some strength to the pound; the net/net result was GBP was little changed since before the vote took place, though did see some very choppy price action. After the dust had settled, the bias for sterling was to the upside marginally, with the pound coming off lows seen in the day against the EUR and GBP.

* NZD: New Zealand Dairy Prices were 1.7% lower (Prev. -5.0%) to $3,222. Whole Milk Powder prices rose by 1.5% to $2,973. There was little reaction in the NZD.

subject: NEW ENHANCED CALENDAR - our new live economic calendar provides you with the quickest delivery of market moving data, now with data supplied by Thomson Reuters
content:
We are pleased to announce that from today our Economic Calendar will have data supplied by Thomson Reuters to ensure you benefit from the quickest delivery of market moving data.

The new feature includes all major tier 1 data as well as secondary data points and will allow you to look ahead and also search for historical data.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Fed’s Powell, UK politics and NZ inflation data in focus
content:
DXY

A firm rebound from just under 94.300 to around 94.800, partly on decent US data (ip and manufacturing output broadly in line with consensus, but embellished by upward revisions to the previous month), indirect impulses and Fed chair Powell reiterating strong economic developments that justify further gradual tightening.

GBP  

Ending a volatile Tuesday session under pressure and underperforming vs G10 peers as UK PM May faces yet another challenge to her leadership and a backlash from pro-EU rebels trying to overturn Customs Bill amendments forced through by Brexiteers yesterday. Reports going in to the Trade Bill vote suggest that Remainers within the Tory party and Labour opposition will join forces to back their own amendment to essentially keep Britain in a customs union if there is no new trade deal by January 2019, and also reject a motion from the PM to break for Summer 5 days early (which would cut the amount of time to mount any challenge against her). Cable has lost grip of 1.3200 having climbed above 1.3250 on solid UK jobs data (earnings less so) and has tested support around 1.3150, while Eur/Gbp got to within a whisker of 0.8900.

NZD/CHF

Relative outperformers vs the aforementioned reinvigorated Greenback, the Kiwi on buoyant core NZ inflation and notwithstanding a mixed GDT auction – dairy prices down again, but whole milk up. However, Nzd/Usd has slipped towards 0.6800 vs 0.6840 at best, while the Franc holds around 0.9950.

EUR/AUD/CAD/JPY

All on the backfoot having reversed earlier gains relative to the Usd, with the single currency unable to clear 1.1750 and now around 1.1700, Aud retreating with its antipodean counterpart from overnight peaks above 0.7400, Loonie weakening towards 1.3200 again and not really deriving any independent support/impetus from much better than expected Canadian manufacturing sales. Meanwhile, Usd/Jpy absorbed more supply stacked above 112.50 to trade very close to its recent high near 112.80, but is holding below reported 113.00 barriers.

content: Further gains for bonds as another set of in-line US data with upward revisions is largely overshadowed by events elsewhere, and this time more Brexit related risk for PM May and her increasingly divided Government. Hence, Gilts have now been up to 123.39 (+42 ticks) and just 10 ticks shy of last Friday’s peak, while Bunds are even closer to chart resistance at 162.86 (162.85 best, +38 ticks). Meanwhile, the Pound has handed back all of its post-UK labour data gains and more, with Cable down to a sub-1.3150 low and Eur/Gbp testing 0.8900.  All this before Fed’s Powell.

subject: PRIMER: Fed Chair Powell Dual-Testimony to the US Senate (Tues, July 17) and the US House (Weds, July 18)
content:
• Fed’s Jerome Powell – who since his appointment as chair, has generally tended to avoid rocking the boat in his public addresses – will be testifying in his capacity as Fed chair, so will likely repeat the themes from the June FOMC meeting minutes; Powell will likely give a nod to the Fed’s current economic and rate projections, which look for two more rate rises in 2018, as the Fed normalises policy gradually.
  • TRADE WARS: The subject of trade will feature heavily, not only because of the economic implications, but also the political nature of the subject (and the Testimonies). The FOMC’s June meeting minutes showed that the Fed is cognizant about global trade risks, noting that these risks had intensified and were concerning; the central bank’s contacts have also expressed concerns about how tariffs might impact investment, the minutes showed, with some contacts also suggesting that capital spending has already been scaled back. In an interview last week, Powell continued on the theme, sounding a note of caution with regards to the state of global trade, stating that there is a rising level of concern about the effects of changes in trade policy, any trade disputes or high tariffs will be a negative for the economy.
  • WAGES: In his interview last week, Powell was upbeat about the state of the economy, with unemployment rate low and inflation near target. Regarding wages, Powell said that while the labour market is strong by any measure, low wage growth remained a puzzle.
  • FISCAL STIMULUS: There was another note of caution with regards to inflation/fiscal stimulus, warning that it would be challenging for the Fed to raise rates while the economy was weakening. Powell believes the fiscal stimulus will support the economy over the next three years.
  • YIELD CURVE: His comments on the shape of the yield curve will be of note, given that the gap between 2-year and 10-year Treasury yields narrowed to a fresh low around 25bps last week; the recent FOMC meeting saw staff present theories on the yield curve, apparently concerned that any inversion could be a signal of a recession.

content:
Earnings

  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – Q2 EPS beat expectations at USD 5.98 versus an expected 4.66, and revenue USD 9.40bln vs. Exp. USD 8.74bln. Q2 FICC revenues were 45% higher Y/Y at 1.68bln. Net revenues in the equities division was USD 1.89bln, flat versus Q2 2017. Separately, David Solomon will take the role of CEO in October, and current CEO Lloyd Blankfein will remain chairman until the end of the year. (Newswires)
  • Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) – Reports Q2 adjusted EPS at USD 2.10 (Exp. 2.07), and revenues at USD 20.8bln beat the expected 20.39bln. JNJ cut its FY sales guidance. Worldwide consumer sales were up 0.7 Y/Y (domestic sales were 0.7% lower, international sales were up 1.9% and were therefore offset by a positive currency effect of 1.9%). (Newswires)
  • Netflix (NFLX) – The online streaming service reported Q2 2018 EPS at 0.68, missing the consensus 0.80, while revenue slightly topped expectations at USD 3.98bln (expected 3.934bln); subscriber metrics were soft, with domestic subscriber additions at 0.67mln in Q2 versus an expected 1.2 mln, and international subscriber additions were 4.47mln, short of the expected 5.0mln. the co. also gave soft guidance for Q3 subscriber numbers. (Newswires)
  • Omnicom Group Inc (OMC) – Company reported Q2 EPS at USD 1.60 beating the expected 1.55, but revenue was a touch light at USD 3.86bln versus an expected 3.9bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • United Technologies (UTX) – The industrial company’s Pratt &Whitney unit is confident that it can meet engine production demands, and will be able to overcome supply chain issues to raise engine production levels next year, as its order books grow; the company aims to output 60 narrow body aircraft per month in 2019.  (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – Supermarket hires former Humana (HUM) executive as senior vice president, adding to speculation that the two companies are looking to form a tighter partnership in healthcare. WMT has also established a strategic partnership with Microsoft (MSFT) to accelerate its digital transformation in retail. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • Campbell Soup (CPB) – The packaged foods producer disclosed that it received a notice of an unsolicited mini tender offer by Ponos Capital to purchase 5.95mln shares (1.98% of the outstanding stock), and urged shareholders to reject the offer. (Newswires)
  • ConocoPhillips (COP) – The oil and gas explorer provided a strong update on its operating plan for its Alaska business, estimating first oil in 2024-2025, and once first oil is achieved, it anticipates ramping quickly to full production. (Newswires)
  • CVS Health (CVS) – In a request for information from the Trump Administration regarding drug prices, an executive said it supports the Administration's goals and the measures it has taken to keep drug costs lower. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – The industrial company is still working with advisors to determine the best course of action for its GE Capital unit. GE is seeking to divest parts of the unit, and looking for a way to reduce the remaining parts, or separate the entire division. (Newswires)
  • Whirlpool (WHR) – Co.’s CEO said to be more cautious on steel and aluminium tariffs – after initially welcoming the moves which hit competitors LG and Samsung – as they have been impacting supply costs. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Micron (MU) – The company and Intel (INTC) announced they will conclude their 12-year partnership to develop 3D XPoint technology in the first half of 2019, and development beyond the second generation of 3D XPoint technology will be pursued independently by the two companies. (Newswires)
  • PepsiCo (PEP) – The food and beverage company will replace Dish Network (DISH) in Nasdaq 100 index, effective 23 July. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Groupon (GRPN) – IBM (IBM) is seeking USD 166.5mln damages from Groupon in a patent lawsuit, and has alleged that GPRN is using four patented technologies. (Newswires)

analysis_details:
• As a reminder, following May giving into Brexiteers yesterday, pro-remain Conservatives have tabled an amendment to the Trade Bill calling for May to agree to join a customs union with the EU if she fails to get a trade deal by 21st Jan'19
  • The pro-EU group believe they have at least 10 Tory MPs onside with more potentially set to join the ranks and thus potentially set May on course for a defeat with Labour also backing the motion.
  • Furthermore, Labour are also set to vote against the early recess motion put forward by May which was called in attempt to close the window for any potential Conservative leadership challenges. 
  • If May was to suffer defeat on the Trade Bill and there was no early recess, some in the Conservative Party might try and oust the UK PM.

PREVIEW: Fonterra GDT Dairy Auction – futures churn again, but rebound in prices overdue?
content:
The most recent auction saw the headline GDT price index plunge 5% to USD 3,232, while whole milk powder prices plummeted 7.3% to Usd 2.905.

WMP futures are steady yet again ahead of today’s auction, suggesting not much deviation in prices from July 3, but the risk bias must be for some stabilisation, if not a recovery following the sharp drop last time. An unexpected bounce in prices may well add further fuel to the NZD that has been boosted by firm core inflation data overnight (RBNZ’s preferred measure accelerated to a 7 year high).

Back to the GDT, although there is no set time for the release, results were out around 15.15BST last time, but typically can appear from 14:00BST.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 17th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • European equities trade mostly negative (Eurostoxx 50 -0.5%, DAX -0.2%)
  • GBP resilient in wake of another Government semi U-turn on post-Brexit proposals
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US industrial production, APIs Inventories, Fed’s Powell

ASIA 
Asian equity markets traded mostly lower after a lacklustre lead from the US where energy underperformed amid a slump in crude and Nasdaq futures took a hit after-market on disappointing earnings and subscriber numbers from Netflix. ASX 200 (-0.6%) was negative with the index dragged by losses in energy names following a decline of around 4% in oil due to concerns a supply glut could return and as miners suffered from early weakness in Shanghai metal prices. Conversely, Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) bucked the trend on return from the extended weekend amid JPY weakness, while Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (-1.3%) led the declines despite continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC, amid overhang from trade uncertainties and with energy names pressured. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with prices subdued amid a positive tone in Tokyo stocks but with downside also restricted amid the BoJ’s presence in the market concentrated in the short end and belly of the curve. 
 
NDRC said China faces large difficulties in achieving stable development during H2 amid shocks from trade tensions but added that China has ample of space to deal with shocks. (Newswires) 
 
PBoC injected CNY 70bln via 7-day and CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 90bln. (Newswires) 
 
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6821 (Prev. 6.6758) 
 
Chinese House Prices (Jun) Y/Y 5.0% (Prev. 4.7%). (Newswires) 
 
BREXIT 
The UK government narrowly curbed a defeat on the Custom Bill after compromising with Brexiteers demands. The House of Commons approved (voting 305 to 302) the clause to prevent the UK collecting taxes on behalf of another territory or country, unless this were done on a reciprocal basis. 
Subsequently, Conservative Eurosceptics have declared that they have killed off UK PM May’s Chequers plan by making her adopt changes that will leave it ‘dead on arrival’ in Brussels. (Telegraph) Remain-supporting MPs are said to be furious with May caving to the demands of the Eurosceptics. (Times) 
UK Defence Procurement Minister and Remain advocate Guto Bebb resigned after the government accepted ERG amendments. (Newswires) 
EU/UK/US 
UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) May 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.7% (Prev. 2.8%) (Newswires) UK Average Earnings (+Bonus) May 2.5% vs. Exp. 2.5% (Prev. 2.5%, Rev. 2.6%) UK ILO Unemployment Rate May 4.2% vs. Exp. 4.2% (Prev. 4.2%) UK Claimant Count Unemployment Change Jun 7.8k vs. Exp. -2.1k (Prev. -7.7k, Rev. -3.0k) 
 

EQUITIES 
European equities trade mostly negative (Eurostoxx 50 -0.5%, DAX -0.2%) in what has been a relatively light session thus far in terms of newsflow. European markets have opted to shrug off the broadly softer Asia-Pac lead which saw sentiment hampered by yesterday’s declines in energy prices and slump in Nasdaq futures after Netflix subscriber growth figures fell short of street estimates. 
In terms of sectors, telecom names lag their peers after Orange (-1.4%) were cut to neutral from buy at Citi and Telenor (-1.8%) earnings fell short of market expectations. Material names are seen higher despite ongoing trade concerns as gains in Thyssenkrupp (+8.3%) lift the sector amid news that their Chairman is to leave the Co., following the recent resignation of their CEO. 
Other individual movers include Casino (+3.8%) who are higher following encouraging sales figures which has also pulled Carrefour (+1.5%) higher in sympathy. Royal Mail’s (+2.0%) latest trading update has been welcomed by the market, whilst Tom Tom (+4.7%) shares have headed north after upping their revenue and EPS guidance. 

FIXED INCOME 

A very well received if not strong German 2 year auction has helped core bonds regroup after the earlier downturn that continued in wake of the UK labour report on certain encouraging metrics, like the low unemployment rate. Bunds have rebounded to a marginal new intraday peak at 162.80 and Gilts towards their previous session high of 123.26, while Schatz futures are mid-range and 7 ticks above their previous close. US Treasuries a bit more mixed, but only marginally either side of parity with the curve fractionally steeper ahead of IP data. 

FX 
NZD/AUD - The Kiwi is now head and shoulders above the G10 pack on elevated NZ inflation data, but not the headline measures that were actually a tad softer than expected. Instead, it was the RBNZ’s preferred core or factor model measure that hit a 1.7% y/y 7 year peak that boosted the Nzd to 0.6840 vs the Usd and not far from 1.0860 vs the Aud, which lagged in wake of neutral RBA minutes flagging heightened global trade risks due to hyped up import tariff threats between the US and China amongst others. Aud/Usd remains above 0.7400 on a broadly soft Greenback, but is still wary about option expiries at the strike through this week, with 800 mn falling today. 
CHF/EUR - Both benefiting from the ongoing Dollar retracement off recent peaks (DXY circa 94.300 and drifting further vs 95.243 last week), with the Franc pivoting 0.9950 and single currency consolidating above 1.1700, but capped ahead of 1.1750 after testing resistance around 1.1740 (top of a cloud base). 
GBP - Resilient in wake of another Government semi U-turn on post-Brexit proposals, with Cable rotating around 1.3250 and Eur/Gbp circling 0.8850 following UK labour data showing underlying strength in the jobs market, albeit with wages still not reflecting high levels of employment perhaps. 
CAD/JPY - Relatively flat vs the Usd with the Loonie just off highs in a 1.3110-40 range ahead of Canadian manufacturing sales data, while Usd/Jpy meanders between 112.25-55 with heavy offers layered above 112.50 and markets looking towards US ip data for some further direction. 

COMMODITIES 
WTI and Brent (+0.1% and +0.3% respectively) crude futures trade in close proximity to recent lows as market forces continue to act against the commodity. Prices have been unable to make any meaningful recovery from recent losses which have stemmed from ongoing concerns that a supply glut could return amid reports the US is open to considering waivers on Iran sanctions, Libyan refineries coming back online, as well as recent chatter that the US was mulling dipping into the strategic petroleum reserve. In terms of energy newsflow from today’s session, Libyan sources report that domestic oil output has risen to 650-700k bpd as ports continue to re-open. With this in mind, Goldman Sachs state that they still expect Brent crude to retest USD 80/bbl although it may occur in late 2018 rather than previous forecast of summer, citing US stance on oil. 
In metals markets, spot gold (+0.36%) has seen some modest support from the broadly softer USD with traders mindful of today’s congressional testimony from Fed Chair Powell. Elsewhere, copper is seen higher by around 1% in London trade as LME inventories remain tight, whilst steel prices were seen lower overnight as recent Chinese data poses some concern for the market. Finally, Indian government sources suggest that the nation is still in talks with the US regarding the rolling back of steel tariffs with India ready to impose safeguards if necessary.

RANsquawk EU Mid Session - 17th July 2018; Rebel Rebel, Brexit is a mess
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European equities have pared back their modest opening losses to trade with little in the way of firm direction (Eurostoxx 50 -0.2%, DAX +0.1%) in what has been a relatively light session thus far in terms of newsflow. European markets have opted to shrug off the broadly softer Asia-Pac lead which saw sentiment hampered by yesterday’s declines in energy prices and slump in Nasdaq futures after Netflix subscriber growth figures fell short of street estimates.

In terms of sectors, telecom names lag their peers after Orange (-1.4%) were cut to neutral from buy at Citi and Telenor (-1.8%) earnings fell short of market expectations. Material names are seen higher despite ongoing trade concerns as gains in Thyssenkrupp (+7.0%) lift the sector amid news that their Chairman is to leave the Co., following the recent resignation of their CEO.

Other individual movers include Casino (+3.9%) who are higher following encouraging sales figures which has also pulled Carrefour (+1.5%) higher in sympathy. Royal Mail’s (+2.8%) latest trading update has been welcomed by the market, whilst Tom Tom (+3.9%) shares have headed north after upping their revenue and EPS guidance.

FX

NZD/AUD - The Kiwi is now head and shoulders above the G10 pack on elevated NZ inflation data, but not the headline measures that were actually a tad softer than expected. Instead, it was the RBNZ’s preferred core or factor model measure that hit a 1.7% y/y 7 year peak that boosted the Nzd to 0.6840 vs the Usd and not far from 1.0860 vs the Aud, which lagged in wake of neutral RBA minutes flagging heightened global trade risks due to hyped up import tariff threats between the US and China amongst others. Aud/Usd remains above 0.7400 on a broadly soft Greenback, but is still wary about option expiries at the strike through this week, with 800 mn falling today.

CHF/EUR - Both benefiting from the ongoing Dollar retracement off recent peaks (DXY circa 94.300 and drifting further vs 95.243 last week), with the Franc pivoting 0.9950 and single currency consolidating above 1.1700, but capped ahead of 1.1750 after testing resistance around 1.1740 (top of a cloud base).

GBP - Resilient in wake of another Government semi U-turn on post-Brexit proposals, with Cable rotating around 1.3250 and Eur/Gbp circling 0.8850 following UK labour data showing underlying strength in the jobs market, albeit with wages still not reflecting high levels of employment perhaps.

CAD/JPY - Relatively flat vs the Usd with the Loonie just off highs in a 1.3110-40 range ahead of Canadian manufacturing sales data, while Usd/Jpy meanders between 112.25-55 with heavy offers layered above 112.50 and markets looking towards US ip data for some further direction.

FIXED INCOME

A very well received if not strong German 2 year auction has helped core bonds regroup after the earlier downturn that continued in wake of the UK labour report on certain encouraging metrics, like the low unemployment rate. Bunds have rebounded to 162.69 and Gilts towards 123.20 from the low 123.00 area, while Schatz futures are mid-range and 7 ticks above their previous close. US Treasuries a bit more mixed, but only marginally either side of parity with the curve fractionally steeper ahead of IP data.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent (+0.1% and +0.3% respectively) crude futures trade in close proximity to recent lows as market forces continue to act against the commodity. Prices have been unable to make any meaningful recovery from recent losses which have stemmed from ongoing concerns that a supply glut could return amid reports the US is open to considering waivers on Iran sanctions, Libyan refineries coming back online, as well as recent chatter that the US was mulling dipping into the strategic petroleum reserve. In terms of energy newsflow from today’s session, Libyan sources report that domestic oil output has risen to 650-700k bpd as ports continue to re-open. With this in mind, Goldman Sachs state that they still expect Brent crude to retest USD 80/bbl although it may occur in late 2018 rather than previous forecast of summer, citing US stance on oil.

In metals markets, spot gold (+0.36%) has seen some modest support from the broadly softer USD with traders mindful of today’s congressional testimony from Fed Chair Powell. Elsewhere, copper is seen higher by around 1% in London trade as LME inventories remain tight, whilst steel prices were seen lower overnight as recent Chinese data poses some concern for the market. Finally, Indian government sources suggest that the nation is still in talks with the US regarding the rolling back of steel tariffs with India ready to impose safeguards if necessary.

However, latest claimant count, employment and wage updates could easily alter the tone if outside consensus and against the backdrop of relatively lofty August BoE tightening expectations.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 17th July 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly lower after a lacklustre lead from the US amid underperformance in energy names and Netflix earnings weighing on Nasdaq futures
  • The UK government has managed to avoid defeat on its Customs Bill after caving into the demands of Brexiteer MPs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, UK labour market report, US industrial production, APIs, BoE’s Carney, Fed’s Powell and supply from Germany

 

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly lower after a lacklustre lead from the US where energy underperformed amid a slump in crude and Nasdaq futures took a hit after-market on disappointing earnings and subscriber numbers from Netflix. ASX 200 (-0.5%) was negative with the index dragged by losses in energy names following a decline of around 4% in oil due to concerns a supply glut could return and as miners suffered from early weakness in Shanghai metal prices. Conversely, Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) bucked the trend on return from the extended weekend amid JPY weakness, while Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) and Hang Seng (-1.0%) led the declines despite continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC, amid overhang from trade uncertainties and with energy names pressured. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with prices subdued amid a positive tone in Tokyo stocks but with downside also restricted amid the BoJ’s presence in the market concentrated in the short end and belly of the curve.

NDRC said China faces large difficulties in achieving stable development during H2 amid shocks from trade tensions but added that China has ample of space to deal with shocks. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 70bln via 7-day and CNY 30bln via 14-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 90bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6821 (Prev. 6.6758)

Chinese House Prices (Jun) Y/Y 5.0% (Prev. 4.7%). (Newswires)

UK/EU

Notable Cross Border Tax Bill Amendment Votes:


- UK House of Commons voted (316 to 289) against New Clause 11 of the Cross-Border Tax Bill which would have made establishing tariff free access to the EU as a negotiating objective for the UK Government.
- House of Commons voted (305 to 302) to approve New Clause 36 which prevents the UK collecting taxes on behalf of another territory or country, unless this were done on a reciprocal basis.
- House of Commons voted (303 to 300) to approve Amendment 73 which commits the Government to having a separate VAT system to the EU.
- House of Commons voted 318 to 285 to approve the third reading of the Cross-Border Tax Bill which progresses the bill to the House of Lords. (Newswires)

- House of Commons voted (316 to 36) against New Clause 16 which would have required approval from Scottish Parliament to implement some of the powers in the Bill.

Subsequently, Conservative Eurospectics have declared that they have killed off UK PM May’s Chequers plan by making her adopt changes that will leave it ‘dead on arrival’ in Brussels. (Telegraph) Remain-supporting MPs are said to be furious with May caving to the demands of the Eurosecptics. (Times)

UK Defence Procurement Minister and Remain advocate Guto Bebb resigned after the government accepted ERG amendments. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was lacklustre overnight but consolidated around the 94.50 level, while EUR/USD saw mild gains after support held at 1.1700 and GBP/USD attempted to nurse some of yesterday’s Brexit-related declines which were triggered by the UK government’s acceptance of amendments proposed by hard-line Eurosceptic MPs. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses were slightly higher on the return of Japanese participants, while AUD/USD was initially choppy after the RBA minutes stuck to reiterations before it later coat-tailed on NZD outperformance after the RBNZ’s preferred inflation gauge rose to its highest in 7 years which overshadowed the earlier softer than expected CPI data.

RBA minutes from July 3rd meeting stated the board judged it was appropriate to maintain policy and that the next rate move is likely to be a hike if the economy improves as expected but added it saw no strong case for a near-term change. The minutes also noted that AUD had declined slightly but remains in range of the past 2 years and that recent data consistent with view for GDP to increase a bit more than 3% in 2018 and 2019. (Newswires)

New Zealand CPI (Q2) Q/Q 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.5%). (Newswires)
New Zealand CPI (Q2) Y/Y 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.1%)

New Zealand RBNZ Q2 sectoral factor model inflation Y./Y at 1.7% vs. Prev. 1.6% during Q1; highest in 7 years. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures flat near the USD 68.00/bbl level after the prior day’s 4% declines due to concerns a supply glut could return amid reports the US open to considering waivers on Iran sanctions and with refineries coming back online, as well as recent chatter US was considering dipping into the strategic petroleum reserve. Elsewhere, gold prices traded flat amid consolidation in the greenback and with participants awaiting Fed Chair Powell’s testimony later, while copper was higher on a continuation of yesterday’s rebound to eye the USD 2.90/lb level.

US Senator Grassley introduced a bill against OPEC 'price fixing' and stated that OPEC output quotas keep prices artificially high. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs said it still expects Brent crude to retest USD 80/bbl although it may occur in late 2018 rather than previous forecast of summer, in which it cited US policies on oil. (Newswires)

US

Yields were higher across the curve in thin volume, with the curve modestly bear-steepening at settlement, which was 2s10s rise by just shy of 1bps, but still within the 25bps handle. Short-dated yields rose to highs not seen in almost a decade ahead of Tuesday’s testimony by Fed chair Powell (See below for preview). There was little by way of major moves in Treasuries after retail sales data, however, losses appeared to be scaling back in afternoon trade as equities, and more noticeably, oil found selling action. US 10YR T-notes futures (U8) settled 6 ticks lower at 120-05+.

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) said policymakers are focused on the flattening of the yield curve and that he is unsure whether the flattening yield curve signals a recession ahead. Furthermore, Kashkari stated that Fed is risking inverting the yield curve by continuing to hike and that there is little reason to raise rates further since doing so could trigger a recession. (Newswires)

Mexico said it will take defensive actions and respond to US trade measures. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade mostly lower amid energy-related losses
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly lower after a similar lacklustre lead from US where energy underperformed amid a slump in crude and Nasdaq futures took a hit after-market on disappointing earnings and subscriber numbers from Netflix. ASX 200 (-0.6%) is negative with the index dragged by losses in energy names following a decline of around 4% in oil due to concerns a supply glut could return and with miners suffering from early declines in Shanghai metal prices. Conversely, Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) bucks the trend on return from the extended weekend amid JPY weakness while Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) and Hang Seng (-0.9%) are negative, despite continued liquidity efforts by the PBoC, as energy names are pressured and amid overhang from trade uncertainties.

FX markets remain quiet with the DXY consolidating around the 95.50 level, while EUR/USD is steady amid support at 1.1700 and GBP/USD languishes after yesterday’s Brexit-related declines in which the UK government accepted amendments proposed by Eurosceptic MPs. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses are slightly higher on return of Japanese participants and antipodeans are indecisive with AUD choppy after the RBA minutes stuck to reiterations, while NZD briefly wobbled following softer than expected CPI data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful with prices flat amid a positive tone in Tokyo stocks and the BoJ’s presence in the market concentrated in the short end and belly of the curve.

PREVIEW: RBA minutes from the July 3rd meeting where the central bank kept rates on hold at the record low of 1.50% as expected, due at 0230BST/2030CDT/0930HKT
content:
The RBA are to release the minutes from the July 3rd meeting where the central bank held the Cash Rate Target at the record low of 1.50%. This was in-line with consensus as ASX 30 Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures had indicated a 100% expectation the central bank would keep policy unchanged.

At the meeting, the RBA reiterated that steady policy is consistent with growth and inflation target and that low level of rates is supporting economy. Furthermore, RBA repeated that inflation is likely to remain subdued for some time and that it expects a gradual pick-up in inflation with CPI expected to be a bit higher than 2% this year, while the RBA also commented that AUD has declined a little and that GDP growth is to average slightly above 3.0% this year and next.

As a guide, markets were unreactive to the actual policy announcement and statement considering the decision was as unanimously expected and with the RBA mostly sticking to reiterations in its statement.
